I was a member of the process air engineering design team for all of the air handling units that provided air at the coating stations, chill box sections and the drier section. Hi, your video just popped up on my YT feed.
I will have to watch in properly later as I am going out, but I worked at Kodak manufacturing here in Melbourne Australia for almost 38 years, (1961-1999)starting in chem prep where we prepared the chemicals for all phases of manufacture.
From Chem prep I spent another 6 years in what we termed E-trials, where on a small 8 inch wide coating track, we test all variations of emulsions on various types of film or paper, then for the remainder of my time, I spent in various laboratories before becoming the lead tech when PC's made their appearance.
What I have seen so far has stirred up a lot of fond memories of the friendships I have made and all the hard work we did in a family friendly environment, looking forward to seeing more.

Greetings, Dustin! I've long enjoyed watching your videos, and I'm always quite impressed with your thorough, logical approach to examining a given problem or situation.

Now, I have a question that I'm hoping you can help me find an answer to, as it adresses a possible threat to public safety.

First a bit of background; my wife and I drive a tractor-trailer, and like many long-haul units, our cab is equipped with a bunk, so that the off-duty driver can get some sleep.

However, it is often quite difficult to get to sleep at all, while careening down the road at highway speeds, dealing with constant twists, turns, inclines, declines and, worst of all, ENORMOUS potholes; it is no exaggeration to say that some of them literally LAUNCH my extremities flailing into the air!

Now, I have found on occasion that it can be easier to fall asleep sitting up in the passenger's seat, yet my wife objects to this, as she fears the practice sub-consciously "trains" one's body to sleep in an upright position, making it more likely to fall asleep while driving.

Now, my question is; is it less dangerous to build a "habit" of sleeping upright, or to try and force oneself to sleep prone, with little to no success? After all, isn't ANY form of sleep better than virtually none at all?

I'm desperately seeking an answer to this dilema, as I'm certain that many other drivers deal with this same issue, and as such it poses a danger to public as well as personal safety!
If this is something you feel you may have the resourses to investigate, I'm certain that countless drivers and commuters could benefit from your efforts!

An aside to this video. The gelatin making process. The choice of the bone and specifically "What the animal ate"!  This solves the unanswered subject matter of a long and boring report I read concerning gold cupellation. They tested all these bone ash cupels. They figured out regardless of the controls on the process some cupels absorb more gold and silver than others along with the lead. Various companies, various batches from those companies. They did all kinds of observations and tests and couldn't figure out why. Some cupels only absorbed 2mg, most around 22mg and some as much as 80mg. Well, this answers that question. Some animals from some areas and some animals from certain ranches will have varying levels of minerals in their diet. I.E. Their bones... background mineral content

I work as part of an industrial controls engineering group; the control room Jeff takes Destin to has the computer screens displaying the results of what industrial controls do out on the floor. Every temp, every flow rate, every compound amount, and every machinery part (motor, belt, valve, gate, etc.) has a signal that goes back to a computer program that displays those screens in the control room. Industrial control systems can be incredibly complex, but they're present in almost every process in the industrial world today. My job is never boring!

My favorite Kodak film was Kodachrome 64. Fine grain resolution, wide contrast ratio, beautiful color saturation when shot 1/2 - 1 stop underexposed. Also, Slide film has no negative that needs a positive print made. Slide film is a positive negative (that's awkward) and light is shone through. With print film, someone is making a decision how to print from your negative. You had something in mind when you took photo. Processor has no clue what your photo is supposed to be. They use 'average' when picking exposure. No human touch, all by machine. Custom printing is available, but cost more. Many times it's worth it if photo is important. You can order multiple 'proofs' at different exposures; 1 under, average, 1 over.

Actually I suspect the green light in the elevator is special: the spectral sensitivity peak of the human eye lands in the greens, which means that less green light is needed for the same amount of apparent lighting. That then ostensibly leads to less bleaching, which is the main, and slower, mechanism of adaptation to lighting conditions.

In submarines they use red light, on the other hand, because the eye is the least sensitive to that and so you can preserve night vision. So I'd suspect the so called dark floors in the Kodak building aren't quite as dark as to take the eye into the scotopic region -- makes sense because they work with color film -- but maybe into the low photoscopic to mesoscopic range. Then suddenly low intensity green light is the best option instead.

I've been a film fan since the 60s (highschool) where I would shoot 10 or so rolls (100 foot) of film per year for school and personal projects. I tried a LOT of diffferent film manufacturers, but Kodak was always my 'goto' stock. Usually Tri-X for sports/outdoor things, but good old Plus-X for usual stuff (all black and white due to processing cost back then.) I started fiddling around with Ectachrome in 1968 using the old E-6 (a truly magical film at the time.) I did almost all of my own processing. But it was always a 'black box' as to how they made the film. This series has finally unlocked the process and covered it in incredible detail. I would have thought most of this would have been secret sauce*. I finally have a real understanding of what goes *IN to the process that makes my task of taking and developing work so well. What is being shown in this video was once very secretive.  Very few people were allowed to see the process, and most of this was considered top secret.  The formulation of the emulsions and the equipment designs were carefully guarded secrets. This is Building 38 and it cost more that $1 billion in 2022 dollars to build it.  This was the last coating facility built by Kodak in the USA.  It was meant to be the flagship coating facility and meant for production of motion picture film.  Thankfully there are still some  directors who want to shoot their movie on film.  But those days may be coming to an end.

What often goes a bit unnoticed amongst all the cool machining and engineering work around the actual production is large scale fully automated storage.
My dad wrote the software for a huge storage of a really big manufacturer for all kinds of drugstore products in the early 90s. The storage was actually split across 3 locations, and communication back then was done via an analog (!) phone line between two, directional radio between another pair, and a cabled serial connection for the final pair. During commissioning some of these had a hickup and the whole system basically forgot EVERYTHING. They had to re-inventory it ALL over the course of a weekend, because monday morning products had to roll in and out again. He basically did a 48h shift there, and it's amazing to me that this was even possible back then on such a scale.

The angular air-roller is super  neat! The whole air-conveyor is! When you're dealing with a 2Km long film that's about the thickness of a human hair, any uneven friction could warp it and any surface defect would tarnish it. Eliminating the friction entirely instead of trying to maintain 2Km of regular rollers is brilliant, any unevenness of surface of the air-rollers doesn't matter and they don't wear out or vibrate out of alignment. It's a really clever approach imo.

I worked in 'film sensitizing' for 35 years, retired in 2004. What you saw here was Building 38/38 machine. At one time there were 5 more, not sure how many they have decommissioned since '04. When film was more popular, before digital, 14 room (coating machine) and 13 room (coating machine) ran 24 hours a day 360 days a year, non-stop! I have done every job in the coating/sensitizing process, including 'Head Coater', that is responsible for the entire room (machine). When I retired I worked on a problem solving team,  similar to the governments DARPA unit. Solving problems that were 'impossible' to solve. LOL  There were, and are a lot of great people there doing an almost impossible job.  Think of it as manufacturing a product with zero defects. Then unlike a car, there is another dimension, it is also light sensitive!!   8)  Thanks for the look back!    --gary

You might find this interesting…  I had a portrait studio for many years.  Another pro a couple of towns over once did a wedding, back in  the medium format 220 rolls days.  Somehow 10 out of 12 rolls where spun backwards by mistake.  Kodak knew it had happened but they were only able to track the labels to the retailer but did not know where they would show up.  So the pro had like 48 negs from a wedding that should have had over 200.  Since the emulsion side went through the camera backwards, those two pro-pack were all bad.  When they reached out to Kodak they made the couple and the photographer a deal….  They refunded the parents all of the photographers fees and then offered to pay the photographer to re-do all the images, pay to fly everyone back in, re-rent all of the venues and cakes and dresses and hairdresser, flowers, everything.   OR cut the couple a nice check for $12k to start their new life together.  They took the money.  This was in the 1980s so that was a ton of money.  I thought that was very good customer service.

My family has been in the professional photography business for over 140 years. In my lifetime I visited Kodak Park several times, the last was in the late 1970s. I assure you none of the machines you saw in this video even existed. It was all done by hundreds of extremely talented people, many who had been Kodakers for many years. Computers were just coming into use. What you saw here was, if my memory serves, amounts to less than 20% of the film base manufacturing and emulsion coating capabilities of Kodak Park at its peak. Keep in mind in those pre-digital days, Kodak had probably a hundred different emulsions and most were available in many different sizes. What you saw here was the coating of color NEGATIVE film. A completely different division manufactured photographic paper-- beginning with the paper base itself. In 1978, Kodak have THREE huge paper mills at Kodak Park just to keep up with the demand. The one constant between then in now are the people... first class all the way.  One other aside, ALL the machinery then was designed and built at Kodak Park. Kodak Apparatus Division had a mile long plant across the road. It is now a parking lot.

I found an old Kodak Report and used it to extrapolate some ballpark numbers. Final result = 5664.14 troy ounces of silver for every roll of film base spliced into the chain! That's $97,083.36 of silver per roll of film base at todays prices! No idea how many splices are made on a typical production day... 😮

No wonder Kodak used to offer a silver recovery program to film labs! Holy smokes!

In case anyone wants to check my figures:
-Kodak report specifies 12g of silver per 100 sq-cm of 35mm film (average of 6 most popular film products sold in 1998)
-Roll of film base is approx. 1-meter wide by 1761.744 meters long (per first video) yielding 17,617,440 sq-cm
-That gives approx. 176174.4 grams of silver per roll of film base (above figure /100 sq-cm)

I had worked in a small photo shop opened by my relatives and we basically did what you described in part 1, just very small.
We did our work without a dark room, we had a heavy card box layered with thick cloth where we put our hands in and do the chemicals. It's not a big problem because a decade ago is the all time low of film photography and only one to two very old chap would show up with a plastic film every week, thats actually the reason we lost the dark room, it cost too much rent and no one is using it.
But, the fun thing is, we still had that photo machine and it was from the 70's which is magnificent in printing quality, out performing modern technology quite a lot and people came to our shop with digitals just because we could print better.
Sadly my relative is almost reaching 70 and he has decided not to fix the printer and retire if it breaks down, and it broke 5 years ago which ended my story there. Not sure where all the tools ended up in, he said he sold it to a local guy who imports the inks and chemicals for him, maybe some of the parts are still running on other existing printer in my country.

Its amazing but really strange watching this video. An amazing amount of time, effort and money went into designing and building this facility. It was built at the tail end of film photography, before DSLRs were a serious contender, so it made sense to invest this much into it. But now, it feels like a still living, but dying facility. A still existing relic of a time past. Run by old men, who might never be replaced when they retire. When the facility reaches end of life, its unlikely to be replaced by a facility with a similar capacity.

But despite being obsolete by other technologies, there is still an incredible amount of knowledge of producing films contained within. And when the people running this facility retire, that knowledge might be lost. Even though photographic film might be past its prime, I'm sure there are still many scientific or other high end applications that have no replacement for high quality film. And it will be a massive loss for those fields when they are no longer able to make use of the massive investments that have been made into this technology.

One of the coolest parts about the casket storage to me, assuming it's anything like the automated racking systems I've seen in my work, is that it's not organized.

If the computer knows how many of each product you have and where it stuck them when you put them in, it doesn't care if they're colocated or consistent like we might. It just has X slots to store stuff and it puts them wherever it can fit. It blows my mind that you can exchange items in and out with the system at a consistent point but "inside the black box" it's organized totally differently than it would need to be if you or I wanted to track it.

In my observation fluorescent lights don't "shut off" when you flip the switch, but gradually over the course of at least several minutes power down (which makes sense based on my understanding of the chemistry involved). If you think that film is fascinating you should look into the adjacent industry of Flexographic printing.

DuPont's campus in Delaware helped develop the modern digital process that is what's used to create almost every single label or flexible package in the market.

The company I work for makes some of the most popular software and hardware for imaging to the photo polymer plates that get loaded onto printing presses. It's an industry I knew nothing about when I started working here, but is one of the more vital pieces of the entire supply chain that no one thinks about. I think you'd be absolutely fascinated by how deep this rabbit hole goes.

Earlier this year, Kodak started making Ektachrome 100 in large 400 and 1000 foot rolls of 35mm for shooting in movie cameras. I also coordinated an effort to buy that film, and package it into 3 100 foot rolls and 18 36 exposure cassettes. All of that had to be done in the dark.
